stem: After reviewing the patient's electronic health record, including the nurse's notes, vital signs, lab results, physical exam, and care plan, determine the primary physiological purpose of each intervention in the management of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
0700: SBAR for Mr. Jones, admitted 0600 today. Pt is a 67-year-old male admitted with suspected ARDS secondary to recent aspiration pneumonia. 
0705: Pt is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Initial settings: FiO2 60%, TV 450 mL, RR 20, PEEP 10 cm H2O.
0710: ABG on vent settings reveals pH 7.28, PaCO2 55 mmHg, PaO2 65 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L, SaO2 90%. Noted increased peak inspiratory pressures (PIP) to 35 cm H2O. Auscultation reveals coarse crackles bilaterally, diminished breath sounds in the bases.
0800: Physician notified of ABG results. Orders received and implemented: Increase PEEP to 14 cm H2O, prone positioning initiated. Monitor vital signs and respiratory status closely.
0900: Patient repositioned prone. Secured all lines and tubes. Pressure points padded. Continuous monitoring in place. 
0930: Repeat ABG drawn. 
1000: ABG results pending. Patient tolerating prone position. PIP decreased to 28 cm H2O. SaO2 increased to 94%. 
1100: New ABG results: pH 7.35, PaCO2 45 mmHg, PaO2 80 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L, SaO2 95%. Physician notified of improvement in ABGs. Continue current plan. Keep HOB >30 degrees when supine. Frequent oral care performed. Skin integrity monitored q2h.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: 06:10: Patient is alert and anxious. Severe dyspnea, productive cough with purulent sputum. Auscultation reveals coarse crackles bilaterally, diminished breath sounds in the bases. Increased work of breathing noted: nasal flaring, intercostal retractions. Skin is warm and flushed. Peripheral pulses are +2 bilaterally.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
- Continuous cardiac monitoring.
- Mechanical ventilation: FiO2 60%, TV 450 mL, RR 20, PEEP 14 cm H2O.
- Prone positioning q2h.
- ABG stat, then q4h.
- CBC with differential stat.
- Blood cultures x2.
- Sputum culture.
- Administer antibiotics as ordered (Piperacillin/Tazobactam 4.5 g IV q6h).
- Suction PRN.
- Oral care q4h.
- Monitor skin integrity q2h, protect pressure points.
- Elevate HOB >30 degrees when supine.
- Continuous sedation with propofol.

rows.text: Increasing Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) from 10 to 14 cm H2O
Maintaining Head of Bed (HOB) elevation >30 degrees when supine

rationale.correct: Increasing PEEP helps to keep alveoli open at the end of expiration, preventing collapse and improving gas exchange. Prone positioning redistributes lung perfusion and ventilation, decreasing V/Q mismatch and improving oxygenation. Elevating the HOB helps prevent aspiration of gastric contents, reducing the risk of further lung injury.
rationale.incorrect: Increasing PEEP doesn't directly improve oxygenation, but reduces alveolar collapse, which then improves oxygenation. Prone positioning helps improve oxygenation but does not reduce alveolar collapse directly. Elevating the HOB does not directly reduce work of breathing or improve oxygenation, but prevents aspiration.

answerBreakdown.text: Increasing Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) from 10 to 14 cm H2O
answerBreakdown.rationale: PEEP increases alveolar pressure at the end of expiration, preventing alveolar collapse. This improves gas exchange surface area and reduces the work of breathing required to re-inflate collapsed alveoli with each breath. The ABGs show improvement with increased PEEP.

Prone positioning helps redistribute lung perfusion and ventilation, reducing V/Q mismatch. It allows previously compressed alveoli in the dorsal regions of the lungs to open up, improving oxygenation. The nurse's note mentions improved oxygen saturation after prone positioning.

answerBreakdown.text: Maintaining Head of Bed (HOB) elevation >30 degrees when supine
answerBreakdown.rationale: Elevating the head of the bed helps prevent aspiration of gastric contents, which can worsen lung injury and ARDS. This is especially important in patients with decreased level of consciousness or impaired gag reflex due to sedation. The patient's care plan includes this intervention.

clinicalPearls: Monitor PIP (Peak Inspiratory Pressure) when increasing PEEP as high PEEP can cause barotrauma.
Prone positioning requires careful monitoring and securing of all lines and tubes to prevent accidental dislodgement.
ARDS is characterized by non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema and hypoxemia that is refractory to oxygen therapy.

questionTrap.trap: Students often confuse the immediate effect of PEEP (preventing alveolar collapse) with its downstream effect (improving oxygenation).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the direct physiological effect of each intervention. PEEP directly prevents alveolar collapse; improved oxygenation is a consequence of this.

mnemonic.title: ARDS Management
mnemonic.expansion: ARDS: Airway management (intubation), Respiratory support (ventilation), Decreased lung injury (prone), Supportive care (fluids, nutrition).
